qas.question: What process causes changes in plant cells?
What is the original cell of the plant?
How are the different cells formed?
How is it determined, which cells will be formed?

answers.text: activation of some genes and inhibition of others

context: <a0_0>Epigenetic changes<a0_0/> in eukaryotic biology serve to regulate the process of cellular differentiation. During morphogenesis, totipotent stem cells become the various pluripotent cell lines of the embryo, which in turn become fully differentiated cells. A single fertilized egg cell, <a1_0>the zygote<a1_0/>, gives rise to the many different plant cell types including parenchyma, xylem vessel elements, phloem sieve tubes, guard cells of the epidermis, etc. as it <a2_0>continues to divide<a2_0/>. The process results from the epigenetic <a3_0>activation of some genes and inhibition of others<a3_0/>.
